setup.question: What best describes how the overall tone changed from the beginning of the article?

Text.text: Lighthearted and tense seems slightly more plausible than upbeat to sympathetic for a fictional passage

Story is as follows:
Eddie is a science nerd excited about the day. His dad, an atomic scientist at a college is getting a shipment of a new radioisotope. However it was stolen before his dad could study it. He honestly seemed pretty chill about it, talking openly with eddie. 

The entire story is through the perspective of Eddie, a kid, and the tone never gets to anything tense. He never sees the theft firsthand, everything we get told via conversations, his dad was concerned but seemed pretty chill. Ending is a long convo between him and his friend's mom, and his friend Teena who he visits after dinner. He explains what radioisotopes are cuz they saw the theft on the newspaper.

Ross family talks about radioisotope but nothing tense ever comes in the convo. It's just a convo, and Eddie is very sympathetic to Teena's mom and dad acting not as cheerful as normal

lmk any evidence u need

Would love some evidence from the beginning of the story too to show it's upbeat, and not lighthearted.

Also please give me the best evidence in favor of tense - what would the other debater present as evidence if they were here?

Lighthearted/upbeat pretty similar but the story is def more upbeat—as in positive/optimistic to future. 
Main beginning of story is setting up how excited Eddie is of the radioactive shipment:

Eddie goes out all excited for the day because of a) the shipment and b) prospecting for uranium ore cuz of a dream. 

ev for tense: in the middle his dad tells Eddie abt the stolen shipment. It goes on the newspaper so his best friend and her mom also knows about it when he goes to see them at the end. The ending is convo between Eddie, Teena (his friend) and Teena mom. They have no idea what radioisotopes are so Eddie explains radioactivity and the possible dangers of it to them. 

Keep in mind that why I don't think tone is tense is because 90% of the story is just convos of eddie and the dif characters: some 'tense' ev:
ran out of ev but can cite their convos if u like.

Yeah please fill up quotes next turn too. This feels really hard for me to adjudicate given the similarity between the answers and the kind of question. Can you give context around the "tense" quotes you gave? How about 100 tokens before 3439 and after 3614?

lmk what else you need. I mean the main reason why the tone does not turn "tense" is because nothing dramatic is happening. The whole story, again, is just conversations between a kid and his family and neighbors. I think later on in the story when (guessing from the title of the story) Eddie will get into more tense/dramatic scenarios but in the meantime there is no danger/foreboding-ness. 

I can give more ev for B as well that appears more throughout the ending. The ending convo where eddie talks with his friend teena and her mom is quite lighthearted. They make jokes when the two ask eddie to teach them about radioisotopes.

Can you actually fill in the gaps in your quotes? Just want to confirm the breaks are for space reasons and not to cover anything up.

And yeah more ev for B in the end would be helpful too!
i just didn't want the quotation marks to use up space but sure.

kinda messy here but shouldntbe in the quotes tab
